threads.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

last_replies.com:
OP I'm no photography expert but if you're thinking about buying a camera I urge you to consider going the analogue route:
>Every shot costs money so you are forced to choose your images wisely, basically gives you a 'quality over quantity' attitude to taking photos
>Introduces a new variable for you to experiment with (the film) so gives you more possibilities with just one camera
>If you ever want to take a photo that doesn't justify using film, you can use your phone since the quality won't matter for that photo anyway
>Photos look nicer in general
>No batteries
>Typically smaller than digital camera (obviously depends, but typically this is true)

just something to think about if you're looking at actually buying a camera.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Probably soon I'm going to get a Olympus TG-6, with the idea of mainly taking macrophotography on the field (lichen, small plants, etc). The durability in rain is very appealing for where I live. My phone takes pretty good photos but doesn't work great for closeups.

threads.com:
Hi there. Not sure if anyone remembers my thread asking about the utility of using amphetamines during hiking, but I gave it a shot. Nothing too crazy happened, this doesn't end with me getting arrested or raped by the rape dwarves, but I feel like it's interesting enough to share.
I chose a really long hike that loosely followed a train line so at any time a bailout point wouldn't be *too* far away and so that I could go for as long as I could. I carried a backpack with only a few candy bars and some electrolyte powder, and 4L of water with a filter so no matter what i wouldnt dehydrate. Plus other random shit which is less important.
Here's how it went:
>wake up at 3am - want to start early so I won't be limited by dawn
>not that it's approaching summer in the southern hemisphere so i don't need to worry about temperature
>arrive at the start at 430amish and begin
>actually feel quite refreshed because i went to bed early enough to get 7 hours of sleep and debate doing it sober
>nah, i came here for a purpose. i gobble 200mg of caffeine
>an hour or two passes and i feel awake but not much else so not really different to before
>fuck it, down 5mg of plain old d-amphetamine
>distinctly feel it kicking in 15 minutes later. things feel sharper, i feel less fatigue, can maintain pace
>this feeling continues for almost 4 hours!! woah im feeling it now
>note that throughout the entirety of the hike i am occasionally having a candy bar to keep blood glucose up, sports electrolyte powder thingy to stop cramps etc. and regularly making myself drink water even if im not thirsty
>but then
>crash hard and fast. feel like i pulled an all nighter. can still keep moving but i legitimately feel like i would fall asleep if i sat down and closed my eyes
>but i still have so much longer to go!
>so naturally i have another 200mg caffeine and 5mg of the good stuff cuz i aint done
>feel good for a while again but not to the same level
>this time wears off after only 2.5ish hours...
cont

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Got up into my first tree stand today. The ladder felt sketchy but I made it. I didnt have a harness so I know I'm stupid. I used 1000lb non climbing rope to tie a bowline around my chest/under armpits and looped that around the stand, then anchored to the bottom. If I fell I would have at least been caught on the stand, assuming I fell to the left side.

I've got a full body harness that comes with a tree strap coming, as well as 100 feet of 10.5mm UIAA rated static rope and 4 UIAA/CE rated carabiners. I figure in addition to the harness and tree strap, I'm going to make a swiss seat with a carabiner coming off the front, and then clip that into a rope tied around up near the tree belt for the full harness. I figure two harnesses should be safe and make me comfortable up there

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
What are the best methods and gear for sleeping in various conditions?

Mine is currently sleeping mat and sleeping bag, if it's colder I'll be wearing heavier clothes inside the bag because it's just rated for mildly cold (MIN 5C), but for now it's ok because I'm a beginner and doing non extreme stuff.

I would like to buy a carinthia defence 4 because it seems a very good all around bag that I can in both very cold and temperate weather, and even hot nights if I open it but at that point I'd use a wool blanket or nothing.

Are there better methods?
Should I buy a woobie(us milsurp ones seem good)?
Should I buy a wool blanket?
Are there any good alternatives to the carinthia defence 4 that are less expensive?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2496778
Carinthia is great; you can't really make a mistake with their stuff. And Defence 4 is excellent. Had one for years now.

It all depends on your environment. I am Czech, so winters can go -20 C fairly regularly. Defence 4 + Helikon Swagman (a fantastic thing with many uses) always served me well during the coldest nights. I think you could possibly do it even without the Swagman, but since I am pussy, it works for me.
During the Autumn period (about now), I usually just stick with Defence 4 alone. In Spring and summer, it is Carinthia Tropen (+ Swagman again if it gets cold).
For the sleeping mat, I've been using Thermarest Zlite for ages, but over the last few years, I replaced it with Exped Dura 5 inflatable. Extremely comfy all-year sleeping pad. Very durable too. Pricy, though, but well worth it. Shove Bundeswehr elephan skin underneath to be extra safe and you are good.

Other than that, clothing should suit your activity. If you are going to be hiking the whole day, wear just enough to be "comfortably cold." If you are waiting somewhere most of the time, go full marshmallow man.
My go-to for winter is merino undies/base, a simple shirt, and a lighter winter jacket. It is good enough for hiking. At night, when I just stand around, I throw Swagman over my jacket again, which is comfy.

For shelter, I just use a Helikon poncho. It can easily tank whole night downpours/snowing. And it is compatible with Swagman too. One is absolutely enough, but I carry two.

In summer, lmao, who cares.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've worked in multiple national parks so I actually know what I'm talking about.
Every National Park is drastically different with its approach to illegal campers. Generally, the only obstacle to stealth camping successfully is figuring out where to leave your car. Some parks allow overnight parking so they'll only bust you if they see you crawling out of your sleeping bag in the morning. Other parks will give a warning/ticket to any car parked overnight unless you're displaying a permit for backcountry camping. In my park, you'd probably have a 50/50 chance of getting a warning or a ticket if you were busted doing this.
The obvious solution is to leave your car in a National Forest lot, or in town (many parks have free shuttles from town into the park).
Once on the trail, you just have to avoid backcountry rangers who will ask you for your camping permit. Honestly your odds of encountering one of these guys is very low, but all the same it's best to minimize your time on trail, or have an alibi ready.
Wherever you camp, make sure it's well off the trail. Check your map to make sure. Don't leave any trash or light a fire, kthx.

I remember one encounter with a wild boar in the woods when I was starting out.

I was hammock camping. I found a nice place without any high bushes and with trees that were just perfect distance from each other to hang my stuff from. Grass looked like there was an old, forgotten hiking trail there. It's something common here, so I didn't worry about it and set up my tarp and hammock.
Late at night, when I was just chilling and smoking I heard steps and breaking of twigs. Sure enough a fucking boar was getting closer to me - I set up my camp not on an old trekking trail, but on a trail made by wild animals. It was constantly grunting while I was just lying there terrified. When it got close enough to almost touch my tarp it started loudly sniffing. Then it loudly snorted in clear disgust and left.

Thank god I didn't move or tried to scare it away. Later I learned that boars when frightened are more likely to attack than to run away. Smell is a good way to deter wild animals. Not being a complete retard that sets up a camp on animal tracks and trails is also a good idea.

>>2489351
just in case foreigners want to visit, here is a few tips for norway
>national parks
you have almost unlimited freedom going outdoors everywhere here, national parks are just more crowded and ironicly more limited. doesnt apply for all parks but no need to look for parks exclusively.
>fjords/lofoten
everyone seems to want to go there but its highly overrated and if its a travel through or roadtrip thoose places lead you away from so much else. consider if that one epic instagram pic that everyone takes is worth everything you miss.
>trails
same as parks, you can go everywhere so why go there? many trails are either the shortest route from cabin A to cabin B or they follow old travel routes that was also shortest route from A to B. rarely the most scenic or interesting. hiking here is mostly above forest limit (thats low altitude since we are far north) so finding directions is pretty easy without trails.
>camping
do not under any circumstance googlemaps campsite or camping, its not what you think. its boomers or poor families with kids cramped into small pay-per-night spots with a few accomondations like shower and toilet. wildcamp instead, again everywhere.
only time you should consider a "campsite" is if you need a shower or you want to rent one of the few cabins they often have. its not an outdoorsy experience and can be loud and crowded.
>cabins in the wild
public unguarded cabins exist but a bit hard to find and you never know if they are taken. some cabins require membership and key, some are staffed and serve hot meals. or you can rent your own on airbnb or inatur.no.
>fishing
coast/sea is unlimited
inland requires fishing license, but if no one see you no one cares... do not try it in salmon rivers their landowners are crazy and will shoot at you.
>hunting
a bit more paperwork but can be done as a foreigner on small game and birds

threads.com: Is black more stealthy and versatile than camo?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2498024
Mogged

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Nobody uses black for anything because of how badly it silhouettes.
Very, very few things in nature are black. You're the only black think in the entire woods.

Lighting up less than everything around you means you're standing out, shadows are similarly visible because they move when you move.

Many black things are also reflective, or more specifically carry some kind of reflective coating.

Thus real camo exists primarily to blend in while remaining visible.
Break up your outline, avoid reflection, make look less like a moving object.

All kinds of shit moves in the woods, people notice certain kinds of movement. Specifically anything geometric which is drifting (like and specifically an eye). Our brains are programmed to ignore swaying in order to pick out something that's actually moving in a particular direction.

Your black watch?
Yea that's a geometric reflection moving from left to right, visible at 500 yards.
Your black jumper?
Solid silhouette moving left to right, 500 yards.
I might not know what I'm looking at, but i sure as shit see it.

A factor people often forget is at what distance certain things are visible. Pattern is incredibly visible at close range but quickly disappears.
Shape on the other hand remains visible at very long distances.

I'm 5 miles away, what meter square signal will get my attention?
A mirror flashing light at me.
A square moving at right angles
A simple orange square
A black square against the skyline, a white square against the treeline
A pattern of some kind.

So you see, you could actually use black as a fairly effective signal, a black square moving up and down against the skyline is right up there with an orange square and a giant mirror.

Your black backpack going up and down as you try to spy on me from a ridge is as good as waving a flag.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
So you see some of the best camo has a very high contrast, some spaces almost black, some almost white.
Some people fear the highlights, but in doing so they merely appear as a solid black shape and make their camo less versatile (flektarn).
That's why multicam is unironically better than flecktarn, at close range friendlies see the squares- but at long range the very high contrast breaks up your silhouette very effectively and stops one part of your body silhouetting against another part, your camo won't accidentally form a frame which makes your backpack into the dreaded geometric object tracking left to right. Granted it helps to bring dessert colors into a desert but it was far better than the flat olives and grays.
If US forces all went in ghilli suits they would have shot more of each other than the Taliban.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

There are basic principles of camouflage:
Shape,
Shadow,
Shine,
Silhouette,
Colour,
Movement.
These are the things that will get you spotted.
Is black more stealthy? Only at night. Otherwise innawoods you're a large black object on a green background, therefore highly visible.

>A detailed description of the truffle dog was given by the English sports writer John Henry Walsh in his The Dogs of The British Isles (5).

The truffle-dog is a small poodle (nearly a pure poodle), and weighing about 15lb. He is white, or black-and-white, or black, with the black mouth and under-lip of his race. He is a sharp, intelligent, quaint companion, and has the "homing" faculty of a pigeon. When sold to a new master he has been known to find his way home for sixty miles, and to have travelled the greater part of the way by night.

He is mute in his quest, and should be thoroughly broken from all game. These are essential qualities in a dog whose owner frequently hunts truffles at night - in the shrubberies of mansions protected by keepers and watchmen, who regard him with suspicion. In order to distinguish a black dog on these occasions, the hunter furnishes his animal with a white shirt, and occasionally also hunts him in a line.

These dogs are rather longer on the leg than the true poodle, but have exquisite noses, and hunt close to the ground. On the scent of a truffle (especially in the morning or evening, when it gives out most smell), they show all the keenness of a spaniel, working their short-cropped tails, and feathering along the surface of the ground for from twenty to fifty yards. Arrived at the spot where the fungus lies buried, some two or three inches beneath the surface, they dig like a terrier at a rat's hole, and the best of them, if let alone, will disinter the fungus and carry it to his master. It is not usual, however, to allow the dog to exhaust himself in this way, and the owner forks up the truffle and gives the dog his usual reward, a piece of bread or cheese; for this he looks, from long habit, with the keen glance of a Spanish gipsy.

Yes, you won't have a good grip on the wall otherwise. They need to fit like a glove, when you become more advanced you'll start using climbing shoes that really fucking hurt in the beginning
>And are your toes supposed to hurt after climbing?
A bit, depends on the shoes and what you're climbing
>What are some cheap ones that are ok?
La Sportiva Tarantula were my starting shoes, I really liked them but have advanced to Scarpa Veloce for bouldering and Booster for sport climbing
>it’s easier for short people, is this true?
Depends a lot. Some routes and bouldering problems are easier for shorter people but in general being taller is an advantage. I'm 5'10 and have to work at lot less on some boulders and routes compared to my wife who's 5'6
You develop better technique from the height disadvantage though
>climbing outdoors was much different and harder than indoors, even with the same ratings. Is this also true?
For boulders that's 100% true until you reach a certain grade, the easier ones are a lot harder outdoors than indoors

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2496901
I think it's better to consider them to be uncomfortable as opposed to painful. Any kind of pain suggests there are hot spots, meaning the shoe might not be too small but instead the wrong shape for your foot and you should instead try a different model.
I downsized 1.5 sizes in my instincts; I have to pop the heel out between climbs but they are never painful...
On the other hand I have pair of pinks that are 0.5 sizes down and cause searing pain in all my toes as they're too narrow...
Finally note that how much you downsize depends on the make as well as the model. For example, I'm true to size in Unparallel but go 3.5 sizes down in La Sportiva

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Yes, they hurt. You'll build calluses.
Go to your local REI and get some used shoes if you want real cheap, but go for the tarantulace or defy lace for new shoes. As tight as you can without being outright painful. Toes can curl a little bit. Get a BD Momentum Harness if you plan on doing top ropes, no shame in starting in bouldering though. You'll get used to chalk but yeah it feels gross. Try liquid chalk if you can't get over it. Climbing outdoors is much harder, everything indoor is controlled (temp, holds, spaces between, angles, etc). Don't bother tradclimbing until you're beyong great indoors.

>triple stitching is BETTER than single or double
sure i will agree, but gear actually designed for what you're doing is better than gear that isn't.
let's use pants as an example. sure some military pants might be triple stitched and rugged but the crotch area is still going to be sewn together like picrel. using a stock photo of jeans for convenience, the stitching pattern's just about the same. fine for walking, but it will be the first point of failure if you climb or cycle in them. my hiking pants from a recreational company were designed with these things in mind and have a gusseted crotch and won't prematurely blow out. pants with a standard pattern develop holes in the crotch really quickly from either of these activities. yes my pants might *only* be double stitched but they will last much longer because they're designed for what i use them for.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2494739
>hermitage
If you were there in summer, I would recommend Pymatuning Reservoir which has very good boating and paddling. You can go ice fishing there if you're into that and have the equipment for it. Misery Bay at Presque Isle is another good spot for that. PA has 1, 3 and 7 day temp fishing licenses that run from $27-35 for OOS residents. Ohio's tourist fishing licenses run from $14 (one-day) to $25 (for three days).

Being right off I-80, you could also drive to Central PA and hike part of the Standing Stone Trail, Mid-State Trail, and Tuscarora Trail. The SST has some excellent dayhiking options like Thousand Steps and Throne Room. Very rocky and scenic hikes with superb views.
This site also has useful info for hiking and backpacking in the area:
https://www.summitpost.org/northern-allegheny-plateau/171825

Yes, you should bring way more stuff. You should bring way more food and water. I've been to the outback and so many niggers fail to bring adequate supplies, I have even had to give some abo niggers water when I was out Wilcannia-Broken Hill way.
Here's a suggested list for you anon:
>Around 42 litres of water (might want to bring more if you want water to wash your stuff with)
>tarp (shade for when you are meditating)
>Poles (for the tarp)
>At least 2 main meals a day (for instance a packet of noodles or a packet of creamy pasta, these are readily accessible at supermarkets, if it cooks off of hot water than you should be good)
>Some sort of stove to heat said water (rocket stove, metho stove, gas stove, jetboil etc)
>Base layer (such as a set of thermals)
>Shorts and a shirt (I would suggest a long sleeved shirt)
>A warm jumper/jacket and long pants
>A hat
>At least a -5 Celsius rated sleeping bag
Some additional stuff to bring if you choose:
>Beanie, gloves, shegmah, tea and or coffee, hot sauce (will make your food taste better), flashlight, firearm, baby wipes and some deodorant. I may have forgotten some stuff but this is just things I could think of. Going to the desert with limited food or water is no joke, it is a slow and agonising death.

>"DIY MRE GUIDE"
>yup, two packs of ramen for your monthly sodium intake, 4 KitKat bars for your corn syrup dose, 2 cans of Spam for the colon cancer nutrients, and some more candy in case you need even more fucking sugar

I don't know if you've had to deal with this sort of nonsense, and I know you anons probably don't need this, but I still wanted to share it.
Here's my recipe for making an actually nutritious and practical MRE that can keep you alive sustainably without caking your fucking arteries with lard.

MEAL 1:
>4tbsp milk powder - 150 calories, protein, fat
>100g oats - 300 calories, carbs, fiber
>50g berries, dehydrated - 60 calories, vital nutrients
MEAL 2:
>150g beans, dry - 250 calories, fiber, protein
>200g whole rice, dry - 250 calories, fiber, carbs

Boil rice, 2x volume of water. Cook beans, 1.5-2 times volume of water. Season rice with a packet of onions sauce, IF DESIRED - add a bit of hot sauce to beans, AVOID PROCESSED HOT SAUCE.

MEAL 3:
>150g of lentils, dry - 350 calories
>100g hardtack - 300 calories
Boil lentils in 2x volume of water, use salt and pepper to season. Break up hardtack, throw into the pot, enjoy poor man's lentil "chowder."

SNACK:
>100g peanuts, unsalted; banana, dried; 150 calories
>30g 70% dark chocolate - 170 calories, antioxidants, fat, protein, very energy dense
>drink 4L of water, daily, replenish your fluids

SPICES:
>Coghlan's 8-in-1 spice dispenser
>onions sauce packet
>tabasco

Supplement heavily with found plants and vegetation, read up on what you can and cannot eat beforehand.
You need fresh food; as healthy as I tried to make it, you cannot fucking survive on dehydrated shit forever, at least not if you want to live long.
Eggs, small game meat, and other things like that can be found with some work.
Mushrooms are your friends if you know how to find the right kind.
